RAHUL JADHAV
+1 (520) 427-4280 | rjadhav@arizona.edu | https://rj27905.github.io/portfolio/
College of Humanities,
University of Arizona,
Nov 25, 2024
Dear Hiring Committee,
I'm writing to the University of Arizona to show interest in the Hindi/Urdu tutoring
position in the Critical Languages Program. I am excited to support your goal of
encouraging language learning and intercultural competency as a native Hindi speaker
with a wealth of academic and professional expertise in developing stimulating learning
settings and fostering cross-cultural communication.
As I’m a student from Indian origin and Hindi as my first mother tongue language, I
believe I am a perfect fit candidate for this position. I developed my public speaking and
cultural exchange abilities while serving as a representative for the International Model
UN and interacting with a variety of organisations. My capacity to effectively engage
participants was highlighted by this event, and I plan to use this talent while developing
interactive, student-centered language sessions.
I proved my ability to work well in interdisciplinary teams, manage project timetables,
and analyse complicated data in my position as an undergraduate research assistant at the
University of Arizona. My ability to create structured curricula, offer helpful criticism,
and keep correct records all necessary for this position was enhanced by these
experiences, which also improved my analytical and organisational abilities.
Furthermore, I am able to incorporate technology into education because of my academic
background in computer science and data analytics automation. In line with
contemporary pedagogical techniques, I can use digital technologies to improve tutoring
sessions and support the development of grammar, pronunciation, and study skills.
This job especially appeals to me since it combines my love of teaching and language
skills with the chance to advance intercultural understanding. I'm dedicated to creating a
nurturing atmosphere that helps students reach their language objectives and enhances
their understanding of Hindi and Urdu culture.
Thank you for considering my application. I would welcome the opportunity to discuss
how my skills and experiences align with the goals of the Critical Languages Program.
Sincerely,
Rahul

Installation Guide for Komatsu Haul Trucks with Updated Operator Cab
Introduction
1
INTRODUCTION
This guide explains how to install Modular Mining’s PTX mobile platform with N231 radio on Komatsu 
830, 930, and 980 haul trucks with Updated Operator Cab.
Note the following:
• This guide applies to PTXC7 Windows CE, PTXC7 Linux, and PTX7 Linux field computers. The 
guide refers to the devices collectively as PTX. 
• PTXC7 Linux devices are PTXC7 Windows CE devices that have been converted to a Linux OS. 
As a result, they have the same part number as PTXC7 Windows CE devices. PTX7 devices are 
factory installed with a Linux OS.
• All PTXC cable harness part numbers also support PTX7, even thought the name specifies 
“PTXC.”
• If the mine selected the PTXC10 or PTX10 field computer for the larger display, this guide also 
applies. The only differences are that PTXC10/PTX10 have slightly higher power consumption 
and mounting kit differences.
1.1
PRINTING THIS GUIDE
To ensure that this guide prints as intended, disable PostScript pass-through on your printer 
before printing:
1
In the PDF file, select File > Print to display the Print window.
2
Click Properties to display the Print Properties window.
3
Select Disable from the PostScript Pass through menu:
If the guide does not print correctly with PostScript pass-through disabled, select File > Print > 
Advanced > Print As Image in the PDF file before printing.

Installation Guide for Komatsu Haul Trucks with Updated Operator Cab
Before You Begin
2
BEFORE YOU BEGIN
Do not install the PTX mobile platform unless Modular Mining’s hardware pre-configuration visit 
achieved the following:
• Personnel know where to install each hardware component. 
• Personnel know the possible routing of conduit.
• All required approvals were obtained.
• The Hardware Pre-Configuration Document was completed and signed by all designated mine 
personnel.
3
SAFETY WARNING NOTICES
Warning:Always verify with the OEM/customer where to connect to power on the vehicle. And DO 
NOT ASSUME the ground location is valid. Check ground with a multimeter to avoid damaging the 
Modular Mining or OEM system. 
Warning:When choosing cable runs, to prevent tripping hazard, do not place cables in walkways or 
standing areas. Also, do not run cables near sources of excessive heat, such as engines or air 
conditioning units, as this will damage cable integrity leading to shorts and expose the system to 
electrical fires. 
This guide contains the following Warning notice on page 14:
Warning:If a power output is enabled on a communication port, do not connect the port directly to 
an OEM device (that is not designed for it) without first terminating that cable without power. 
Otherwise, damage to OEM systems may occur. To terminate an RJ45 Ethernet cable without 
power, refer to Proc Conn RJ-45 Large OD Wire No PWR (PN 250038).
This guide contains the following Warning notice on page 15:
Warning:Make sure you cut the blue and blue/white wires (12V DC power) when terminating the 
Ethernet cable with the RJ45 connector or you will damage the laptop or PTX unit or both.
This guide contains the following Warning notices on page 55:
Warning:To help prevent multipath errors and signal loss, any metallic structure (masts, panels, 
boxes, etc.) within two feet of any GPS antenna should never be above the antenna's ground plane 
height. As a general rule, the antenna's view of the sky to the horizon should be as free from metallic 
obstructions as possible.
Warning:Do not supply power to the N231 radio unless the radio is connected to an antenna, or you 
may damage the radio.

General Welding Guidelines
4
GENERAL WELDING GUIDELINES
The following welding guidelines are for mine staff or mine contractors. Modular Mining employees 
shall not perform any welding activities.
Welding Guidelines
Always refer to and follow the equipment manufacturer’s standard welding guidelines.
Follow all mine-specific requirements and procedures for welding.
If specific equipment manufacturer’s welding standards are not available, welders should follow a 
local industry standard welding guideline, such as, but not limited to:
• AWS (American Welding Society).
• ISO (International Standards Organization).
• CSA (Canadian Standards Association).
• AS/NZS (Australian/New Zealand Standards).
Before welding, ensure that the main power of the equipment is completely de-energized and 
locked out for safety.
Protect all MMS components with welding protection materials. Welding protection materials may 
include welding blankets, welding curtains, and welding screens. The welding protection materials 
must be high heat resistant, non-flammable, non-melting, and spark-resistant. You must use the 
materials to isolate, cover, and protect all Modular Mining hardware components (hardware, 
enclosures, conduit, coax cables, power cables/wires, wiring harnesses, antennas, etc.) from:
• Sparks.
• Welding slag.
• Molten metal.
• Extreme high heat.
• Arc from heavy welding.
• The torch flame.

• ISO (International Standards Organization).
• CSA (Canadian Standards Association).
• AS/NZS (Australian/New Zealand Standards).
Before welding, ensure that the main power of the equipment is completely de-energized and 
locked out for safety.
Protect all MMS components with welding protection materials. Welding protection materials may 
include welding blankets, welding curtains, and welding screens. The welding protection materials 
must be high heat resistant, non-flammable, non-melting, and spark-resistant. You must use the 
materials to isolate, cover, and protect all Modular Mining hardware components (hardware, 
enclosures, conduit, coax cables, power cables/wires, wiring harnesses, antennas, etc.) from:
• Sparks.
• Welding slag.
• Molten metal.
• Extreme high heat.
• Arc from heavy welding.
• The torch flame.
Do not connect welding ground leads directly to any Modular Mining hardware, enclosures, 
masts, etc.
Do not lay welding cables over or near the equipment electrical harnesses. Doing so might induce 
welding voltage into the electrical harness and cause damage to components.
Fully cover all finished welds with rust-inhibiting paint. The paint color should match the color of 
the surrounding base surface and should be approved by the controlling maintenance department 
for each equipment type.
Modular Mining recommends inspecting all welds as part of standard system checks. Repair or 
repaint cracks or other visible defects, as necessary.

Prepare for the Installation
5
PREPARE FOR THE INSTALLATION
5.1
PERSONNEL REQUIRED
• Mine safety representative to review the planned installation.
• Project manager (primary mine contact).
• Maintenance manager and/or maintenance planner.
• Welder to fabricate parts and weld the mounting components to the truck. Work with the 
welder to identify and mark all weld locations. The mounting components include the cable 
clamps for the cable conduit that runs from the N231 radio box to the PTX. 
• Fabricator.
• Electrician.
• Maintenance personnel.
5.2
EQUIPMENT REQUIRED
• Man lift/Scissor lift.
5.3
TOOLS REQUIRED
• Tool Kit 305467 (non-CE items) or 306287 (CE items). For European installs, 306287 must be 
purchased, with arrangements to acquire non-CE items locally.
5.4
DOCUMENTATION REQUIRED
• This guide.
• The sales order, which lists the components ordered for the installation. You will need the sales 
order to verify that the mine received all components. Contact the Modular Mining Project 
Manager/Account Manager for a copy of the sales order, if necessary.
• Hardware Configuration Report. The report shows where to install parts on the truck and 
provides other useful information. Contact the Modular Mining Project Manager/Account 
Manager for a copy of the report, if necessary.
• Contact the Modular Mining Project Manager/Account Manager to obtain the following documents:
 
- Router Board RBMETALG-52SHPacn Bridge Configuration Guide. Use this document when 
configuring the N231 radio. 
 - Installing the DISPATCH Mobile Application guide for DE or DE Lite. Use this document 
when setting the PTX unit’s Ethernet parameters for the mine network. 
- Proc Conn RJ-45 Large OD Wire No PWR (PN 250038). Use this document when terminating 
Ethernet cable 106351 in step 2 on page 14.

PLANNING MEETING
Once on site, meet with the personnel involved in the installation. This includes mine personnel, 
Modular personnel, and any individuals who are working within the installation area or could be 
affected by the installation. Inform personnel about the scope of work, share the projected work 
schedule, and conduct a safety briefing in conjunction with the mine personnel.
Meet with the mine maintenance manager or maintenance planner to discuss project requirements 
and determine a projected work schedule. Interference with ore production should be minimized or 
eliminated, when possible. Prioritize installations on down or PM vehicles. Remain flexible and meet

Verify that all parts listed on the sales order were received. Check the packing materials for loose

DISPATCH Mobile Application manual for DE or DE Lite.
• Configure the N231 radio. Refer to Router Board RBMETALG-52SHPacn Bridge Configuration 
Guide.

Differences Between PTXC7 and PTX7
6
DIFFERENCES BETWEEN PTXC7 AND PTX7
• PCAP Glass Touchscreen
• Slightly Higher Power Input Consumption
• Increased Power Output Capability
• Power On Set to “IGN Only” by Default
• CAN Termination - Built In
• PTX IP Addresses
6.1
PCAP GLASS TOUCHSCREEN 
PTX7 includes a Projected Capacitance (PCAP) touch screen, which has a top layer of 1.8 mm 
chemically strengthened glass. As such, it is highly scratch resistant, so no protective overlay is 
required. However, customers may use an overlay if desired. The touch screen is sensitive enough that 
operators may wear gloves when using the screen.
Cleaning the touch screen is similar to cleaning a cell phone. You can use a soft lint-free cloth or 
microfiber cloth. You can also use a small amount of plain water, mild soap, or ammonia-free glass 
cleaner. Apply the cleaning solution to the cloth, then use the cloth to clean the screen. Do not use 
abrasive cleaning products that will scratch the screen.
6.2
SLIGHTLY HIGHER POWER INPUT CONSUMPTION
PTX7 requires slightly more power input at 12.5W (12V input) or 15.0W (24V input) than PTXC7 did 
at 9.2W (both input voltages). This increases by 7.2W if setting the PTX7 to the maximum display 
brightness, which results in a total of 19.7W (12V input) or 22.2W (24V input). This does not include 
any additional power consumption resulting from the use of the "clean12V" or "Power Pass-Through" 
(PPT) power output ports.
6.3
INCREASED POWER OUTPUT CAPABILITY 
PTX7 is capable of 1A of output power on both power output ports. This clean12V is more than the 
PTXC7 series, which provided 770mA. The PPT current is similar and is 1A.
The power output on the Ethernet 1 and Ethernet 2 ports is known as passive PoE because it does not 
adhere to the 48V standard but just provides a DC power output.
• Clean12V output (shared between the DC Jack, COM 3, and Ethernet1). This is enabled/on by
default. This 12V output is from the primary internal DC/DC regulated power supply.

This does not include 
any additional power consumption resulting from the use of the "clean12V" or "Power Pass-Through" 
(PPT) power output ports.
6.3
INCREASED POWER OUTPUT CAPABILITY 
PTX7 is capable of 1A of output power on both power output ports. This clean12V is more than the 
PTXC7 series, which provided 770mA. The PPT current is similar and is 1A.
The power output on the Ethernet 1 and Ethernet 2 ports is known as passive PoE because it does not 
adhere to the 48V standard but just provides a DC power output.
• Clean12V output (shared between the DC Jack, COM 3, and Ethernet1). This is enabled/on by
default. This 12V output is from the primary internal DC/DC regulated power supply.
Note: The max backlight intensity of the PTX7 is much higher than the PTXC7 at around 900 NITs 
(default is 350 NITs) as compared to 300 Nits. Daylight readability is easily achieved without setting 
to the max brightness.

11
Installation Guide for Komatsu Haul Trucks with Updated Operator Cab
Differences Between PTXC7 and PTX7
• PPT output (shared between CAN 1, CAN 2, and Ethernet 2). This is disabled/off by default. 
The output voltage tracks the input voltage closely since it is "passed-through" from the input.
To change the state of the PTX power output ports, you connect to the PTX and run commands that 
are specific to the PTX type. For PTX7, for example, running the sudo ptxapp -y on command 
enables PPT. This is necessary if you need to power CAN devices on the PTXC Cable harness. 
Below are the commands for turning on/off clean12V and PPT on PTX7:
• Clean12V on/off:
•sudo ptxapp -x on 
•sudo ptxapp -x off 
• PPT on/off
•sudo ptxapp -y on 
•sudo ptxapp -y off
Important: Always be careful when connecting the Ethernet ports to external devices as some 
products may be damaged by the presence of "passive PoE" on the unused twisted pairs.
For instructions about enabling PPT for PTXC7 Windows CE, PTXC7 Linux, and PTX7, see Changing 
Power Output Settings on the PTX, If Necessary.
6.4
POWER ON SET TO “IGN ONLY” BY DEFAULT
For more information, see Only if Required: Enable Keep-Alive Mode (PTX7 Only).
6.5
CAN TERMINATION - BUILT IN 
Unlike PTXC7, PTX7 contains an internal CAN terminator in each of its two independent CAN ports. 
The CAN terminators are software configurable and enabled by default. Therefore, take care to avoid 
having redundant terminators at the PTX7. For instructions, see Remove CAN Terminators from 
PTXC Cable Harness (PTX7 Only).
6.6

Changing Power Output Settings on the PTX, If Necessary
9
CHANGING POWER OUTPUT SETTINGS ON THE PTX, IF NECESSARY
Clean12V power output on the PTX is shared between the DC Jack, COM3, and Ethernet 1 and is 
enabled/on by default.
Power Pass-Through (PPT) on the PTX is shared between CAN 1, CAN 2, and Ethernet 2 and is 
disabled/off by default. So, if you need to power CAN devices connected to the PTXC cable harness, you 
must enable PPT on the PTX. 
Note: On PTXC Windows CE devices, the PPT power output is called PoE in the firmware.
Note: Currently, the only MTS CAN devices that will be connected to the PTXC cable harness 
are Guided Spotting DVI display devices. 
Warning:If a power output is enabled on a communication port, do not connect the port directly to 
an OEM device (that is not designed for it) without first terminating that cable without power. 
Otherwise, damage to OEM systems may occur. To terminate an RJ45 Ethernet cable without 
power, refer to Proc Conn RJ-45 Large OD Wire No PWR (PN 250038).
The tasks are:
• Modify Ethernet Cable 106112
• Physically Connect to the PTX Unit
• Configure the Laptop IP Address to be on the Same Subnet as the PTX Ethernet 1 IP Address
• Enable/Disable Clean12V and/or PPT/PoE on the PTX
• Disconnect the Components

white/blue wires. Follow the instructions in crimping guide Proc Conn RJ-45 Large OD Wire No

9.3
CONFIGURE THE LAPTOP IP ADDRESS TO BE ON THE SAME SUBNET AS THE PTX 
ETHERNET 1 IP ADDRESS
To complete this procedure, you need to know the PTX unit’s Ethernet 1 IP address and subnet mask. 
The default primary Ethernet 1 IP address and subnet mask for PTXC7 Windows CE, PTXC7 Linux, 
and PTX7 are the same: 192.168.0.111 and 255.255.255.0, respectively. 
Note: If the PTX was used previously in the field, you need to obtain the PTX IP address from 
the mine.
1
On the laptop, open the Control Panel.
2
In the Control Panel, click Network and Sharing Center.
3
In the window that appears, click Change adapter settings. 
4
Right-click the laptop’s Ethernet connection icon, such as Local Area Connection, and select 
Properties from the menu. 
5
Double-click Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4). 
6
Select Use the following IP address: 
7
Type an IP address that is on the same subnet as the PTX Ethernet 1 IP address but is different 
than the Ethernet 1 IP address. For example, if the PTX Ethernet 1 IP address is 192.168.0.111, 
you could type IP address 192.168.0.1
8
Type the following Subnet mask: 255.255.255.0
9
Click OK. 
10 Close all windows.

Only if Required: Enable Keep-Alive Mode (PTX7 Only)
10 ONLY IF REQUIRED: ENABLE KEEP-ALIVE MODE (PTX7 ONLY)
The default power-on mode of PTX7 Linux is different from PTXC7 (both Windows CE and Linux) in 
that the IGN signal must rise (become active) after power has been applied to the PTX7 unit. 
Conversely. the PTXC7 will turn on regardless of the timing. This permits the PTXC7 to power on 
when there is no separate IGN signal and the IGN Input has been tied to the PWR Input.
Below is the PTX7 default power on sequence required.
Note that in some installations, such as an AC Shovel install, a separate IGN/Key-switch input to the 
PTX7 may not be available. The workaround to this is to enable Keep-Alive mode in the PTX7. This 
makes the PTX7 behave as a PTXC7 (default setting), where the PTX7 will power on if IGN is high, 
regardless of timing. This is done as follows:
sudo ptxapp -a ON

Remove CAN Terminators from PTXC Cable Harness (PTX7 Only)
11 REMOVE CAN TERMINATORS FROM PTXC CABLE HARNESS (PTX7 
ONLY)
For CAN bus connections, the PTX7 has internal CAN terminators that are enabled by default. This 
is different from the PTXC7, which has no internal CAN terminators. Therefore, when installing 
PTX7, physically remove the CAN 1 (1) and CAN 2 (2) terminators (304639) from the PTXC cable 
harness so you don’t need to change the default configurations of the internal CAN terminators.

This is done as follows:
sudo ptxapp -a ON

11 REMOVE CAN TERMINATORS FROM PTXC CABLE HARNESS (PTX7 
ONLY)
For CAN bus connections, the PTX7 has internal CAN terminators that are enabled by default. This 
is different from the PTXC7, which has no internal CAN terminators. Therefore, when installing 
PTX7, physically remove the CAN 1 (1) and CAN 2 (2) terminators (304639) from the PTXC cable 
harness so you don’t need to change the default configurations of the internal CAN terminators. 
If it is desired to leave a CAN terminator in place, instead of physically removing it, you can turn off 
the corresponding internal CAN terminator in the PTX7, using the commands listed below.
• Turn off CAN 1 port terminator:
sudo ptxapp -c can0 off 
• Turn off CAN 2 port terminator:
sudo ptxapp -c can1 off 
To get the status of the CAN terminators on both ports:
sudo ptxapp -c
Note: In the future, the CAN terminators will be removed from the PTX Cable harness.
Note: These changes persist through power cycling (i.e., permanently stored).

Installation Guide for Komatsu Haul Trucks with Updated Operator Cab
Install the N231 Radio and Omni and GPS Antennas
15 INSTALL THE N231 RADIO AND OMNI AND GPS ANTENNAS
You install the N231 radio and its enclosure (1) onto one of the handrail vertical support posts on the 
cabin side of the haul truck. You install the Omni and GPS antenna assembly (2) onto a bracket that 
mounts onto the handrails next to the radio. 
Warning:To help prevent multipath errors and signal loss, any metallic structure (masts, panels, boxes, etc.) 
within two feet of any GPS antenna should never be above the antenna's ground plane height. As a general 
rule, the antenna's view of the sky to the horizon should be as free from metallic obstructions as possible.
Warning:Do not supply power to the N231 radio unless the radio is connected to an antenna, or 
you may damage the radio.
Important:Install the N231 radio and Omni and GPS antennas on the cabin side of the haul 
truck to minimize the cable run from the antenna to the cabin interior.
Important:The handrail bracket, antennas, and N231 radio enclosure should not block the 
operator’s view from the driver’s seat.

Place a new hacksaw blade into the hacksaw. Each antenna comes with a new hacksaw blade.

Using both hands, cut the tube down the center 
of the electrical tape. Use light pressure and

cut off end of the tube to prevent the fibers from 
tearing.
You should see only minor fiber separation, as 
shown to the right.
e
Remove the electrical tape and wipe the cut 
area to remove any debris.
If the mast is too long and requires a second cut, repeat step 6. Be aware that the hacksaw blade 
will be dulled from the previous cut. You must use extra caution to prevent the blade from 
binding and tearing the carbon fibers. Do not reuse the same blade more than three times.

Connect to OEM Equipment Health-Monitoring Devices
16 CONNECT TO OEM EQUIPMENT HEALTH-MONITORING DEVICES
This section explains how to connect to the Cummins engine, KOMTRAX Plus RPC, Wabtec drive 
system, and PLM payload interfaces, using CAN connections.
16.1
CONNECT TO THE CUMMINS ENGINE AND KOMTRAX PLUS RPC INTERFACES 
To connect to the Cummins engine and KOMTRAX Plus RPC 
interfaces, you connect the CAN J1939 (CAN 2) cable on the PTXC 
cable harness to the CAN J1939 bus (indicated by red heat shrink) 
in the center console. The CAN J1939 bus connector (1) is at the 
bottom of the figure to the right.
Note: The connector assembly might be flipped. The side with two 
ports might be facing down instead of up. If necessary, unclip and flip 
the connector assembly so that the side with two ports is facing up.
1
Remove the gray plug (with white spots) to open the port on the 
connector.
2
Plug the CAN J1939 cable on the PTXC cable harness to the 
opened port.
16.2
CONNECT TO THE WABTEC DRIVE SYSTEM AND PLM PAYLOAD INTERFACES 
To connect to the Wabtec drive system and PLM payload interfaces, 
you connect the CAN third-party (CAN 1) cable from the PTXC cable 
harness to the CAN third-party bus (indicated by black or gray heat 
shrink) in the center console. The CAN third-party bus connector (1) 
is at the center of the figure to the right.
Note: If the CAN third-party connection is not available, contact 
Modular Mining support for assistance.
Note: The connector assembly might be flipped. The side with two 
ports might be facing down instead of up. If necessary, unclip and flip 
the connector assembly so that the side with two ports is facing up.
1
Remove the gray plug (with white spots) to open the port on the 
connector. (Do not remove the CAN terminator with orange spots.)
2
Plug the CAN third-party cable on the PTXC cable harness to the opened port.
